content: The Act may be cited as the "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" and its purpose is outlined. The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" aims to assist communities and health care providers, especially in rural and Native American areas, in developing integrated health care delivery systems. This includes coordinating services for uninsured and underinsured individuals to improve care quality and access. The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" aims to assist uninsured and underinsured individuals by coordinating services, developing infrastructure for effective collaboration among providers, and providing new Federal resources without replacing existing funding for low-income populations. The "Community Access to Health Care Act of 2001" establishes a new subpart V - Community Access Program under the Public Health Service Act to provide grants for strengthening services for the uninsured and underinsured. The Secretary may grant funds to develop integrated health care systems serving uninsured and underinsured individuals, expanding services, and enhancing coordination among providers. Eligible entities include public or nonprofit organizations like Federally qualified health centers. To be eligible for a grant under this section, entities must be public or nonprofit organizations like Federally qualified health centers or hospitals providing a substantial volume of non-emergency health services to uninsured individuals and families. Entities eligible for a grant under this section must be public or nonprofit organizations like hospitals providing non-emergency health services to uninsured individuals and families. They should represent a consortium of providers with the principal purpose of offering a broad range of services. Entities eligible for a grant under this section must represent a consortium of providers with the principal purpose of offering a broad range of coordinated health care services for a defined community, including special population groups like migrant workers, homeless individuals, or those with disabilities. The entity's grant application must represent a consortium of providers offering a range of coordinated health care services for a community, including special population groups like migrant workers, homeless individuals, or those with disabilities. This includes all health care providers serving the community, providing care to uninsured and underinsured individuals regardless of their ability to pay. The grant application must describe proposed activities to further the purposes of the grant, demonstrate the consortium's ability to involve providers who traditionally serve uninsured and underinsured individuals, and develop coordinated systems of care for high-quality services. The grant application must demonstrate the consortium's ability to operate the program, ensure participants are enrolled in public insurance programs, leverage other funding sources, and evaluate program activities for progress. The grant application must show fiscal responsibility, include a plan for evaluation, integrate funding sources for sustainability, and demonstrate a commitment to serving the community. The grant application must demonstrate fiscal responsibility, include appropriate accounting procedures, management systems, and a commitment to serving the community without regard to ability to pay. The grant application must show fiscal responsibility and a commitment to serving the community without considering the individual or family's ability to pay. Priority may be given to applicants with a consortium including public hospitals, Federally qualified health centers, and other providers that are covered entities. The grant application prioritizes consortiums with providers serving uninsured and underinsured individuals in communities with high uninsured rates. The grant application prioritizes consortiums with providers serving uninsured and underinsured individuals in communities with high uninsured rates, who would expand preventive and primary care services, improve coordination between healthcare providers and social services. Grantees may use funds for direct expenses associated with planning, developing, and operating a health care delivery system that provides a broad range of services. It also covers direct patient care and service expansions. The grant funds can be used for various purposes, such as increasing outreach activities and expanding direct patient care services within an integrated delivery system. The grant funds can be used for purposes like increasing outreach activities, improving case management, coordinating transportation to health care facilities, developing provider networks, and recruiting/training staff.
